headline.main: Uncertainty Still Clouds Health Care Law

docs.abstract: As concerns arise about implementing the Affordable Care Act, even among its supporters, the White House has another worry: the law is still not well liked or well understood.

headline.main: Health Coverage Worthy of a Senator

docs.abstract: Forcing lawmakers to get their health insurance under the exchanges set up by the Affordable Care Act may prompt them to make such coverage too attractive, and ultimately weaken the system.
docs.snippet: Forcing lawmakers to get their health insurance under the exchanges set up by the Affordable Care Act may prompt them to make such coverage too attractive, and ultimately weaken the system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Six months after Hurricane Sandy, IceStone, a Brooklyn factory specializing in making hard surfaces like tables, is back in operation because its employees made what had seemed impossible possible.

headline.seo: Empowered Workers Help Revive a Brooklyn Factory Hit by Hurricane
headline.main: Flooded Factory Is Brought Back by Its Workers
headline.print_headline: Flooded Factory Is Brought Back By Its Workers

docs.abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column notes that six months after Hurricane Sandy, IceStone,  Brooklyn factory specializing in making hard surfaces like tables, is back in operation because its employees did the work of expensive contractors, cutting a $2 million to $3 million renovation down to less than $1 million.
docs.snippet: Six months after Hurricane Sandy, IceStone, a Brooklyn factory specializing in making hard surfaces like tables, is back in operation because its employees made what had seemed impossible possible.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a meeting with the advocates for disabled people, New York State’s Medicaid director vowed to hold plans accountable when it came to enrolling the most seriously impaired seniors, participants said.

headline.seo: Advocates Say N.Y. Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Seniors
headline.main: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users
headline.print_headline: Advocates Say Managed-Care Plans Shun the Most Disabled Medicaid Users

docs.abstract: Legal advocates for the disabled tell New York State's Medicaid director Jason A Helgerson that managed care companies are signing up healthier older adults referred to them, but deterring the most seriously impaired people from enrolling in a plan; issues underscore difficulties as Gov Andrew M Cuomo, through Department of Health, moves tens of thousands of Medicaid recipients who need long-term care into managed-care plans.
docs.snippet: At a meeting with the advocates for disabled people, New York State’s Medicaid director vowed to hold plans accountable when it came to enrolling the most seriously impaired seniors, participants said.
